query: You are an experienced medical professional skilled at identifying contraindications associated with Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis. You will be provided with a list of Patient Notes. These include the following note types ['ED Triage Notes', 'Progress Notes', 'H&P', 'ED Notes', 'ED Provider Notes']. Identify the contraindications associated with the following instructions: Instructions for "Active Bleeding": - Clinician's Assessment: Prioritize the clinician's documented assessment over the patient's self-report unless the patient's symptoms are strongly indicative of active bleeding. - Types of Bleeding: Active bleeding can include both internal (e.g., gastrointestinal, intracranial) and external bleeding (e.g., open wounds). - Transfusions: Active bleeding is likely if the patient required a blood transfusion for the current episode. - Hematomas: Hematomas are not considered active bleeding unless explicitly noted by the clinician as currently bleeding. - Drainage & Wound Care: Drainage from a wound, especially in wound care settings, is not considered active bleeding unless it's explicitly noted as uncontrolled or active bleeding. - Monitoring & History: A patient being monitored for bleeding or having a history of bleeding without current evidence is not considered actively bleeding. - Blood in Stool or Vomit: Presence of fresh blood in stool (hematochezia) or vomit (hematemesis) should be considered as active bleeding. - Hemoglobin Levels: A drop in hemoglobin alone does not confirm active bleeding unless associated with clinical findings or the need for a transfusion. However, if hemoglobin levels are critically low or have dropped 1 g/dL within 24 hours, this indicates active bleeding. - Controlled Bleeding: If the bleeding has been controlled or has stopped, it is not considered active bleeding. Please follow the instructions below to complete the task--given the Patient Notes in triple quotes (""). 1. Identify all occurrences of the contraindication 2. If a contraindication exists, output true and store in the "result" field 3. If a contraindication exists, extract the exact text from the Patient Notes and store in the "text" field of a "citation" object in the "citations" field 4. If a contraindication exists, add the following additional information to the "citations" field as additional properties: the closest section title or section category in "section", the name of the note type in "note_type", the clinician name in "author", and datetime in "datetime". 5. If a contraindication does not exist, output false and store in the "result" field 6. If no evidence related to a particular contraindication is in the Patient Notes, output an empty list in the "citations" field. 7. Provide a Reasoning how you arrived at the citation and store in the "reasoning" field 8. Provide the associated indicator name matching the term in "Instructions for <indicator_name>" in the "indicator_name" field for each entry in the list of "indicators". Each entry should have one of the following: [ "Active Bleeding" ]. Example JSON Outputs: Example 1: { "indicators": [ { "indicator_name": "Active Bleeding", "result": true, "citations": [ { "text": "Patient admitted with gunshot wound to the abdomen noted in", "author": "Dr. John Smith", "datetime": "10/10/2021 12:03", "note_type": "H&P", "section": "History of Present Illness" } ], "reasoning": "A patient currently suffering from a gunshot wound to the abdomen is experiencing active bleeding." } ] } Example 2: { "indicators": [ { "indicator_name": "Active Bleeding", "result": false, "citations": [], "reasoning": "No evidence of Active Bleeding in the patient notes." } ] } Do not infer or make assumptions about the contraindication. Always answer using the provided Patient Notes information, and not prior knowledge. Please review your work. Patient transferred to JHBMC given that her oncology acer his established here. Patient is reporting that she has chest pain with deep inhalation She has had progressive worsening SOB and exertional dyspnea. Also noting that she has significant pain from her neck to her hips. Primary chest and abdominal pain described and a sharp deep ache that is worse with movement and palpation. Denies fever chills diarrhea, constipation, melena, BRB. Receives Oncology care here at JHBMC. Last note from Oncology 10/31/22. Has been on ED Course: Vitals: 36.4, BP 129/57, HR 84, spo2 96% on 1L Nc. Labs: WBC 8.29, Hgb 13.3, Plt 108, Na 141, K 4.0, Glu 233, Mg 2.0, Phos 3.4, TSH WNL. EKG: Sinus HR 80s QTC 502 Imaging: CT at OSH: 1. Large left pleural effusion and associated total atelectasis. No residual aeration of the left lung. This is new from the prior examination. 2. Probable hematoma involving the inferior aspect of the left iliopsoas muscle with mild stranding in this region. Patient transferred to JHBMC given that her oncology acer his established here. Patient is reporting that she has chest pain with deep inhalation She has had progressive worsening SOB and exertional dyspnea. Also noting that she has significant pain from her neck to her hips. Primary chest and abdominal pain described and a sharp deep ache that is worse with movement and palpation. Denies fever chills diarrhea, constipation, melena, BRB. Receives Oncology care here at JHBMC. Last note from Oncology 10/31/22. Has been on ED Course: Vitals: 36.4, BP 129/57, HR 84, spo2 96% on 1L Nc. No residual aeration of the left lung. This is new from the prior examination. 2. Probable hematoma involving the inferior aspect of the left iliopsoas muscle with mild stranding in this region.
